moves.1. e4 e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Nf3 g5 4. Bc4 g4: The starting position for all the games in the tourney.
moves.9. Bxf4 Bxf4 10. Qxf4 Qxf4 11. Rxf4 Rf8: The usual series of exchanges in the variation. Now the game really begins.
moves.12... f5 13. exf5 Nec6 14. Re1+: White is the gambiteer and down a piece, so I can't play passively. I have to exploit my time advantage, as Black's Q-side is still undeveloped.
moves.14... Kd8 15. f6 d6 16. f7: I waste no time establishing a promotion threat, further tying down Black.
moves.16... Bd7 17. Ne4 Ne5 18. Bb3: Naturally I do not wish to exchange minors. The Bishop helps guard my advanced Pawn.
moves.18... Nbc6 19. Ng5 Ng6 20. Nxh7: Equalizing the material and threatening to remove the barricading Rook that's blocking KB8 from my pawn.
moves.20... Nxf4 21. Nxf8: A Rook trade, but now I will be able to use the Pawn promotion to win a piece.
moves.23... Nxf8 24. Nxf8: Now it's a matter of simplifying down. My two connected passed Pawns on the K-side loom as endgame threats.
moves.24... Bc6 25. Ne6+ Kd7 26. Nd4: Black's B has nowhere to run. It will be exchanged off the board.
moves.26... Re8 27. Nxc6: By moving his Rook to K1, Black now enables me to completely swap off the pieces.
moves.27... Nxc6 28. Rxe8: Now I will pin his Knight...
moves.30... bxc6 31. Kf2: Now it's a simple matter of advancing my two K-side passed Pawns.
moves.35... Kh6 36. Kf5 a5 37. g5+ Kh7 38. Kf6: Now my King guards the road to KN8.
moves.39... c5 40. h5 c4 41. g6+ Kh8 42. g7+ K: Black resigns. It is mate next move.
